clinical_study.brief_title: Maximum Oxygen Uptake in ACL-injured Professional Soccer Players
clinical_study.official_title: Maximum Oxygen Uptake in ACL-injured Professional Soccer Players

brief_summary.textblock: Our purpose is to evaluate maximum oxygen uptake (VO2max) in ACL-injured professional soccer players and after a six-month period of post-operative rehabilitation, compared to a control group of healthy professional soccer players.

detailed_description.textblock: The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) rupture is considered a major injury and may affect the career of professional soccer players. Surgical ACL reconstruction is often required to treat the resulting knee instability. Although ACL reconstruction is considered a successful procedure in restoring knee stability, literature shows that only 55% of the participants return to competitive sports participation after surgery. Soccer players need technical, tactical and physical skills to succeed, such as good knee function and aerobic capacity. Our purpose is to evaluate maximum oxygen uptake (VO2max) in ACL-injured professional soccer players and after a six-month period of post-operative rehabilitation, compared to a control group of healthy professional soccer players.

primary_outcome.description: Ergospirometric evaluation of maximum oxygen uptake running on a treadmill

secondary_outcome.description: Running economy evaluated on a treadmill
Evaluation of body composition with bioimpedance
Quadriceps and hamstrings isokinetic strength evaluation
Knee function Lysholm and International Knee Documentation Committee questionnaires

arm_group.description: ACL injured professional soccer players submitted to ACL reconstruction.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ACL injury
- professional soccer player
- adult
- male
Exclusion Criteria:
- Multiple ligament injury
- knee effusion
- unable to perform the examination on the treadmill
- ACL reconstruction failure
- reoperation due to any cause during the follow-up period
- goalkeeper
